Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: EasyAuthor - An End User Authoring Tool for Open and Intelligent Technology-Enhanced Assessments.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will research the feasibility of a cloud-based, collaborative authoring tool to achieve an order-of-magnitude reduction in technical skills required to author technology-enhanced assessments (TEAs). Additionally, it will seek to advance the frontiers of TEA authoring beyond individual assessments to encompass the creation of personalized TEA pathways for diverse learners. The effort will explore novel technologies including a symbolic abstraction to enable visual design and implementation of complex programming constructs, and the representation of TEAs as "intelligent objects" interoperable with disparate and proprietary assessment platforms. This effort seeks to break the stranglehold of large organizations on a growing assessments market that marginalizes educators due to barriers of cost and technology skills. It will empower educators by making available easy-to-use tools that enable creation and sharing of open TEAs and TEA pathways to support deeper learning at scale, allowing educators to distribute TEAs in a classroom without being restricted by a proprietary assessment system, triggering the evolution of a peer-to-peer marketplace for teacher-created assessments. This disruption bears the potential to empower educator communities at scale and impact all learners in secondary and tertiary education settings through equitable access to quality assessments.

This project will feature two distinctive innovations. The first is a visual programming environment with symbolic abstraction of complex programming constructs that are imperative for the design and creation of TEAs. This will enable intuitive authoring of complex TEAs by non-programmers (an impossibility today) and break down the biggest friction point for achieving access to TEAs at scale. The second is an open format for representation of TEAs as intelligent objects that are platform agnostic and "embeddable" in any assessment delivery system. This will facilitate distribution and usage of TEAs in browsers and thin client environments without the need for server side functionality mandated by proprietary systems. This will eventually break the stranglehold of proprietary assessment delivery systems that tie TEA access to their platforms. The project will pursue two primary research questions: How efficient and useful is the TEA authoring experience for non-technical educators? Are the TEAs effective in eliciting targeted reasoning and thinking processes? These research questions will help validate the technical feasibility of our innovative use of the proposed tool to enable easy TEA creation and distribution, and the efficacy of the complex TEAs created using the proposed project in providing evidence of target learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Technology-enhanced assessment (TEA) authoring tools are proprietary, architected to be closed, restrict collaboration and distribution, and require extensive technical skills to author high quality TEAs. This Phase I SBIR effort explored two complementary innovations centered on enabling the authoring and easy distribution of TEAs by ‘end user’ educators without advanced technical or programming skills. The proposed innovations and product are collectively referred to as Edfinity.

Innovation 1. We developed a working prototype of a TEA editor in Edfinity to dramatically reduce the time and technical expertise required to author TEAs. The editor was conceived to explore WYSIWYG creation of complex TEAs through symbolic representation of problem parts, layout, randomization, and logic flow to enable rapid authoring of TEAs using a point-and-click interface.

Innovation 2. The second innovation focused on the exploration of a new, open standard for representation of TEAs with a view to embodying them with behavioral intelligence (as opposed to allowing such intelligence to reside within the underlying assessment delivery system) and making the TEAs usable in any assessment delivery platform through an API for interoperability.

As an extension of the two core innovations above, the Phase I effort also explored the definition of personalized learning pathways of TEAs by educators to support adaptive, individualized learning experiences.

Research Objectives. The primary research questions researched were as follows:

How efficient and useful is the TEA authoring experience for non-technical educators? (Usability Study)

Are TEAs effective in eliciting targeted reasoning and thinking processes? (Validation and Calibration Study).

Extensive user feedback and customer discovery interviews revealed that the assembly and modification of pre-existing TEAs was critical to educators, who often start with ‘canned’ collections that can ideally be tailored to an individual educator’s needs. As such, we expanded the focus of usability testing to encompass the assembly and customization of TEAs in addition to TEA authoring. The research studies validated (a) the technical feasibility of an innovative  TEA editor to enable easy TEA creation, and (b) the efficacy of the complex TEAs created in providing evidence of target learning. 

Research Conclusion. Based on the research studies, the TEAs tested seem to be a good start as an effective tool in eliciting targeted reasoning and thinking processes. As the product is fully developed, we plan to run additional validation studies based on this preliminary work to include school studies for the Phase II work plan. The project identified several key conclusions to inform research and development for Phase II.

Impact on Principal Disciplines. This SBIR Phase I project is poised to advance the state-of-the-art in Human Computer Interaction (HCI) by having validated the feasibility of a TEA authoring tool that will achieve an order of magnitude reduction in the technical skills required to author TEAs. Additionally, it will advance the frontiers of TEA authoring beyond individual assessments to encompass the creation of personalized TEA pathways for diverse learners. The project explored and piloted novel technologies including (a) symbolic abstraction to enable visual design and implementation of complex programming constructs, and (b) the representation of TEAs as ‘intelligent objects’ interoperable with disparate and proprietary assessment platforms.

Broader Impact on Secondary and Post-secondary Education. This project has created the building blocks for breaking the stranglehold of large organizations on the mulit-billion dollar assessments market that marginalized educators due to barriers of cost and technology skills. The proposed innovation will empower educators to take control of the assessment creation and distribution landscape using tools that allow end user educators to author and distribute ‘platform agnostic’ TEAs without being restricted by proprietary assessment delivery platforms provided by large publishers. The effort bears the potential to empower large communities of educators at scale and impact hundreds of thousands of learners through affordable access to high quality TEAs.

Conclusion. Our SBIR Phase I efforts successfully established product-market fit, confirmed the feasibility of the technology, field-tested working prototypes, assessed legal and regulatory risks, and developed a viable plan to build out and market the product.
